comments.commentBody: Lovely piece of choreography also/
Should boxers and wrestlers of differing weights box or wrestle each other? Why don't you have propose that?
How about 'just play'. Or maybe: Don't complain about everything and just play. Or maybe - get better and try to play the men. Let's see what equal work really means.

A teacher,

The Cincinnati tournament is best 2-of-3 for both men and women.

Or are you arguing that when Federer (or Djokovic, etc.) destroys his opponents in 2 sets instead of being pushed to a 3rd set, he should be paid less?

What about a player who plays lots of long sets and reaches the semi-finals, but there are few spectators at his matches, and TV never shows him? Should he make less?

The reality is that the top and most popular players on both sides - Federer, Djokovic, Nadal, etc. - and Serena, Venus, Sharapova, etc., and the top players in their respective countries, especially when playing in or near home, bring in most of the fans and much of the revenue. So why not give that small group all the money and pay very little to some of my favorites, who are excellent but don't have a large following?

You can see that the situation is not nearly as simple as commenters here portray it.

Greatest tennis player alive? you're either joking or know nothing about tennis. Stefi Graf is the probably the greatest living female tennis player with Navritalova second. Serena is probably 4th or 5th. Greatest living tennis player is Federer and none of the women listed would even be in the top 50. You have to beat the men to be the best and they will NEVER be able to do that.
My mistake - I was referring to US mens vs US women's teams. Not the sports in general.

Thanks for the compassion.  These people ARE dealing with it, they aren't demanding special treatment. In the 4 corners region of the US, there are hundreds of miles between health care facilities. The nephrologist from our hospital uses his own Cessna to visit the various dialysis centers scattered across the reservations.

This article is stupid.

The entire COUNTY of Lancaster Virginia has 11,000 residents. Yet a tiny town in the middle of that sparse county is supposed to have a psychiatrist, a nephrologist, a dialysis center, a rheumatologist, and every other specialist under the sun?

Guess what happens when a subspecialist opens up shop in a rural county like that -- they go out of business because they don't get enough patients.

Let's stop this stupid game -- if you live in rural America you are going to have to deal with less services available than urban areas. Deal with it!

As I mentioned in my comment, these elders did not contact the Times and say "help us get stuff from the government." That is about the last thing these folks would do. The Times chose to publicize what the Times see as an issue. I very much doubt that anyone in the article sits around waiting for guv'ment help.

Yes, we have voted for the state we live in, and with a few exceptions most of us are pretty pleased with the life we live here. We have turned down Affordable Care, which bothers almost everyone with a brain (including our Republican governor who has tried to get it through the legislature.)

And most of us cannot stand Dick Cheney so you are preaching to the choir on that one.

I'm referring to the big money events, Davis cup etc. I am well aware that most of the tourns are bets of 3 for all. At the end of the day the women's game has never been as good and never will be. To demand equal pay is non-sense.

Susie: two items

First, you know NOTHING about sports if you think that the psychological awareness of the potential of having to play five games, does not enter the picture.

Second, many of the womens games suffer the same statistic and are reduced to two games.

So we are back at square one. But dont let the truth stop feminists from trying to connive another delusional argument.

Most of the men's matches are reduced to 2 games as well.

Case in point: In the photo to the left Roger won in straight sets 7-6, 6-3

In that tournament, Serena played more sets than Roger.

LOL obviously I know more about the sports than you Mister X. Better to reread the original post (and understand it this time) before talking about anything psychological.

Not sure why everyone keeps saying that the men play 5 sets to the women's 3. 5 set tournaments are the exceptions.

Out of 22 tournaments in 2016, only ONE was best of 5. The other 21 were best of 3. The best of 5 tournament final was a 3 set match. If you look at the finals of EVERY tournament in 2016, NONE went to 5 sets, NONE went to 4 sets, approximately 1/3 went 3 sets and the remainder were 2 set matches.

Interesting comment.

I never thought of it that way (nor did many others judging from the comments). Actually, the winner may actually work less hard as they are the stronger player!
Often the men's games are shorter - especially when one player has a big serve.
Wrong - most don't.
Bobby was 55 and Billie was 30...your argument is based upon a man in the senior circuit losing to a woman in her prime...

In 1992, 35-year old Martina Navratilova lost 7–5, 6–2 to 40-year old Jimmy Connors in a "Battle of the Sexes" match. To make the match more competitive, organizers modified the rules to help Navratilova: Connors was allowed only one serve per point, and Navratilova was allowed to hit into half the doubles court. When the match was played, Navratilova was still ranked WTA No. 4 (behind Seles, Graf, Sabatini) and she reached the Wimbledon finals or semifinals in 1992, 1993 and 1994; reached the WTA Year-End Championships finals in 1992; as well as won 10 more singles titles since 1992. Connors was at the end of his career: ranked ATP No. 62 when the match was played; since 1991 he won only one more career match in any grand slam event; since 1989 he failed to reach the final of even small events.

If Serena competed against the top 500 men under the same rules, she would be lucky to win a match.
There is a school of thought that he bet against himself against King. He was a hustler, and that would have been the smart play.
Please do not use Bobby and Billie as an example. Bobby was running the senior circuit at 55 and Billie was 30, in her prime.
I would love to see a system in which most medical providers no longer have to dabble in capitalism.  I know such a system won't come to the U.S. any time soon.

As a provider my charges for individual procedures are set relatively high as a starting point with insurance contract negotiation. My goal is to not "leave money on the table" with one of my 20+ insurance contracts. Hospitals do the same thing. As a patient I receive various provider bills and insurance EOBs (Explanation of Benefits) that list the original charge, the allowed charge after the contractual discount which can be substantial, the amount paid by my insurance, and my remaining payment. In my mind the best benefit of insurance is that they negotiate a steep discount with my providers, sometimes more than 50%, to be in their network. The only people that pay the full list price are those without insurance buffering the cost. Again as a provider, I can provide my list price for a specific service but the amount I will receive and my patient will pay out of pocket depends on which one of my 20+ insurance discount contracts they have. They can all be different. This fact that list price is often the opening gambit in an insurance negotiation explains some of the large variation, even 10X, for a given service or procedure in a given market.

With increasing price transparency of late, this inflated charge master approach to insurance contracting is being replaced by more reasonable and competitive pricing that providers actually expect to be paid. For now, a high list price may not mean much including better quality.

From where he sits now, he is only "3 heartbeats away", as the saying goes. If anyone were to take out both POTUS and VPOTUS, he slides in without pending a dime or making an effort.

So - why should he run?
I think he doesn't want to set foot in that mess of a clown car.

He wont run till he runs. I recall one Paul Ryan using the same playbook to become a speaker.  Maybe this Paul Ryan may follow the playbook of the other Paul Ryan who became speaker (reluctantly of-course!)

Just over a year ago, Paul Ryan was the shinning face of the Tea Party [remember that radical fringe group of Republicans?]. Since Trump and Cruz have successfully knocked the GOP off its axis- Paul Ryan [PAUL RYAN!] now looks like a D.C. establishment insider to their throngs of followers. Instead of a united party rallying for Ryan as a viable contender against Hillary- Trump and Cruz supporters are thumbing their noses in disgust at the thought of a brokered convention. This is a really weird predicament for the GOP.
My guess is the Koch brothers will bring him back later on.

He would never win and he knows it. It's obvious Trump supporters, a significant part of the republican electorate, would turn their backs.

I wish it had to do with the fact that Ryan is a low IQ fraud with policy statements to date that are laughable, but it's too late for him to seek the nomination even from a disgraced Republican Party .
Just like he said he wasn't interested in the Speaker of the house seat...look where he is now!
Will Ryan run for President?  The picking of a nominee in the GOP this year was best summed up by the late 20th Century philosopher, Lawrence Peter Berra.  It ain't over till its over."
It's pretty clear the young Mr. Ryan is in no rush to be President.
